articles.headline: Diverging Debate at Fed on When to End Stimulus
articles.snippet: Although more Fed officials want the bond-buying program to end sooner, Ben S. Bernanke, the central bank’s chairman, said the overall policy would remain unchanged.
articles.abstract: Although more Fed officials want the bond-buying program to end sooner, Ben S. Bernanke, the central bank’s chairman, said the overall policy would remain unchanged.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve Chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Wednesday that the Fed was likely to extend the centerpiece of its campaign to bolster the economy — keeping short-term interest rates close to zero — even as it prepares to wind down another key stimulus program that faces mounting internal opposition.

articles.headline: High-Tech Eyeglasses, Not Made by Google
articles.snippet: New glasses to aid your eyesight — even colorblindness — are available, though they won’t let you browse the Internet while you wear them.
articles.abstract: New glasses to aid your eyesight — even colorblindness — are available, though they won’t let you browse the Internet while you wear them.
articles.lead_paragraph: If someone mentions the phrase “high-tech glasses,” you probably assume that person is talking about Google Glass, the smartphone-on-a-headband that Google hopes to offer for sale next year.

articles.headline: E-Book Ruling Gives Amazon an Advantage
articles.snippet: A federal judge’s antitrust finding against Apple over e-book prices underscores how much the book industry has changed and bolsters the advantage held by the online retailer.
articles.abstract: A federal judge’s antitrust finding against Apple over e-book prices underscores how much the book industry has changed and bolsters the advantage held by the online retailer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, loves disrupting markets. In that regard, he must be having a delightful summer. The book business, once so mired in the past it seemed part of the antiques trade, is up for grabs.

articles.headline: Republicans in House Resist Overhaul for Immigration
articles.snippet: Republicans indicated they would not take up anything resembling the Senate bill, putting in jeopardy the future of sweeping legislation that includes a path to citizenship.
articles.abstract: Republicans indicated they would not take up anything resembling the Senate bill, putting in jeopardy the future of sweeping legislation that includes a path to citizenship.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Meeting for the first time as a group to hash out their approach to immigration, House Republicans on Wednesday came down overwhelmingly against a comprehensive overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws, putting in jeopardy the future of sweeping legislation that includes a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: After Epic Escape From China, Exile Is Mired in Partisan U.S.
articles.snippet: After a year in the United States, Chen Guangcheng finds himself enmeshed in controversies over partisan politics.
articles.abstract: After a year in the United States, Chen Guangcheng finds himself enmeshed in controversies over partisan politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chen Guangcheng, the blind legal advocate who challenged the Chinese government over its harsh family planning policies, is nothing if not a politically astute survivor. He outsmarted the phalanx of guards who kept him under house arrest and then made his way into the American Embassy, setting off a diplomatic crisis that was resolved only after Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton intervened and negotiated his freedom.

articles.headline: Deal Reached to Rein In Overseas Trading
articles.snippet: After a rift, members of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission have agreed on a plan to curb risky overseas trading as a Friday deadline approaches. The agency and European regulators also announced a broad “path forward” for how to jointly app...
articles.abstract: After a rift, members of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission have agreed on a plan to curb risky overseas trading as a Friday deadline approaches. The agency and European regulators also announced a broad “path forward” for how to jointly approach cross-border trades.

articles.headline: Maryland’s Path to an Accord in Abortion Fight
articles.snippet: As a new flash point in the abortion debate focuses on regulating clinics, Maryland’s stricter oversight, spurred by the troubled practice of one doctor, has won rare praise.
articles.abstract: As a new flash point in the abortion debate focuses on regulating clinics, Maryland’s stricter oversight, spurred by the troubled practice of one doctor, has won rare praise.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The 18-year-old woman arrived at Johns Hopkins Hospital by medevac helicopter in critical condition. Her uterus and bowel had been pierced during a late-term abortion that had started in New Jersey and ended at an unmarked, unregulated clinic in Elkton, in northeastern Maryland.

articles.headline: In 2011 Murder Inquiry, Hints of Missed Chance to Avert Boston Bombing
articles.snippet: Evidence appears to tie Tamerlan Tsarnaev to the deaths of three men in a Boston suburb, and some officials say a more vigorous inquiry might have led to his capture and prevented the marathon attack.
articles.abstract: Evidence appears to tie Tamerlan Tsarnaev to the deaths of three men in a Boston suburb, and some officials say a more vigorous inquiry might have led to his capture and prevented the marathon attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: WALTHAM, Mass. — It was the most brazen crime in the memory of this Boston suburb: three men murdered with knife slashes to their throats in a second-floor apartment at 12 Harding Avenue; each corpse precisely positioned, stomach down, head turned a quarter to the right, marijuana sprinkled on top.
articles.byline: By Serge F. Kovaleski and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: GlaxoSmithKline Accused of Corruption by China
articles.snippet: The Chinese government said employees of the British drug giant had used bribes, taken kickbacks and committed other crimes to bolster drug sales.
articles.abstract: The Chinese government said employees of the British drug giant had used bribes, taken kickbacks and committed other crimes to bolster drug sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Chinese investigators said Thursday that executives from GlaxoSmithKline, the British drug giant, had admitted to using bribes, kickbacks and other fraudulent means to bolster drug sales in China.

articles.headline: Microsoft Overhauls, the Apple Way
articles.snippet: The giant software company is creating four new divisions and reassigning nearly every senior executive as it tries to create timely products that consumers want.
articles.abstract: The giant software company is creating four new divisions and reassigning nearly every senior executive as it tries to create timely products that consumers want.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A couple of years ago, a satirical set of diagrams depicting the organization of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and other technology companies made the rounds on the Internet. The chart for Microsoft showed several isolated pyramids representing its divisions, each with a cartoon pistol aimed at the other.
